content:
Currently we send our day1 email an hour after the user signs up. While I think I understand the motivation (let the user play around with stuff before they see the welcome email), I feel like that has a much higher chance of feeling like spam than if the email is more clearly transactional (sent as a part of the signup process, i.e. with no delay).

Also, I think an hour is rarely the right time frame for re-engaging with a product. if I'm checking out a product, I'm usually giving it something like 10 minutes; by an hour later I'm on to something else.

dropbox paper sent me their four welcome emails on days: 0, 2, 5 ,7 (actually, wed, fri, mon, wed, which suggests an algorithm like "add 2 days and round up to Monday if it's the weekend"). I think that'd be a good algorithm for us as well?

Looking for other models, I searched my email for messages from Front -- they seem pretty good at this.

It looks like they sent me just one timed email, a few days in -- a detailed pitch for the one feature they're really keen on convincing people to use (which is to connect their individual work inbox).
But then they pretty often send announcements of new features -- like 1x/mo or more.

good idea, thanks for the Front data.
My current thought is that we should send three onboarding emails:

  • Welcome: link to getting started guides, mobile and desktop apps, ideally a "thanks for being a part of the zulip community"
  • Topics: getting the user to like/understand topics
  • Keyboard shortcuts: another shot at teaching them n, r, End, etc

And yeah, I've found the Front new feature announcements surprisingly useful.
